name: Link Context
shortDescription: Links should indicate their functionality and destination to assistive technology
issueDescription: Visual cues on pages provide context to links or hint functionality to users with sight, even if the links aren't fully descriptive. Screen reader users need to know where a link will take them based on the anchor text without additional context.
issueResolution:
Examples include links to the shopping cart, to the company's Facebook page, to the site's search page, or to other similar destinations.

If the link's anchor text doesn't explicitly describe those destinations, add screen-reader only text describing the destination:

<a href="/cart">
  <span class="sr-only">Shopping Cart</span>
  <svg aria-hidden="true">...</svg>
</a>

name: Font Sizes
shortDescription: Text should be scalable to 200% without loss of content or functionality
issueDescription: When text is scaled to 200%, content may be clipped, overlap, or overflow its container if styles like fixed heights, fixed widths, hidden overflow, or absolute positioning prevent proper reflow.
issueResolution:
Do not use less than 12px font-sizes. Ideally, don't go lower than 14px.

<style>
body * {
    font-size: 15px;
}
</style>

name: Empty Headings
shortDescription: Empty headings should be excluded from assistive technology
issueDescription: Screen reader users use header navigation to skim through pages and quickly learn their topics. If empty headers exist, the header navigation feature breaks, and assistive technology users will find the page very difficult to browse.
issueResolution: Remove empty heading tags from your HTML, or add content to them.

name: Nested Tables
shortDescription: Tables should not be nested
issueDescription: Nested tables are often misinterpreted by screen readers, making it hard for users to follow the intended structure and meaning of the data.
issueResolution:
Avoid nesting tables. Use separate tables with clear headings, and if tables are used for layout, assign role="presentation" or role="none" to each table element.

<!-- Use separate tables with clear headings instead of nesting -->
<table>
  <caption>Sales Data</caption>
  <thead>
    <tr>
      <th>Product</th>
      <th>Q1 Sales</th>
      <th>Q2 Sales</th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
    <tr>
      <td>Widget A</td>
      <td>$1,000</td>
      <td>$1,200</td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

<table>
  <caption>Regional Breakdown</caption>
  <thead>
    <tr>
      <th>Region</th>
      <th>Sales</th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
    <tr>
      <td>North</td>
      <td>$500</td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

<!-- If tables are used for layout, assign role="presentation" or role="none" -->
<table role="presentation">
  <tr>
    <td>
      <table role="presentation">
        <tr>
          <td>Layout content</td>
        </tr>
      </table>
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>

name: Empty List
shortDescription: Lists without items or with a single item should lose the list role
issueDescription: An empty list will still be visible for screen reader users. It may frustrate and confuse users as to whether the list is actually empty or there is a screen-reader/accessibility issue that prevents their screen-reader from reading the list items.
issueResolution:
Remove the empty HTML list tags (UL/OL) or give them aria-hidden=true to make screen-readers ignore them.

<ul aria-hidden="true"></ul>
<ol aria-hidden="true"></ol>

name: Untagged Headings
shortDescription: Headings should be tagged for assistive technology
issueDescription: Text that visually functions as a heading for sighted users should also be tagged as a heading for screen reader users.
issueResolution:
If you specifically coded headings without native HTML tags (like h1, h2, etc.) for SEO reasons or otherwise, use role="heading" and aria-level="1/2/3/4/5/6" (the appropriate heading level) to make sure that screen readers announce them as headings. For example, role="heading" aria-level="3" will be treated by screen readers as a h3 heading.

<span role="heading" aria-level="3">This will be treated by screen readers as a h3 heading</span>

Alternatively, you can directly code those elements as native HTML headings.

<h3>This is a native HTML heading</h3>

name: Iframe Labeling
shortDescription: Iframes should have a descriptive label
issueDescription: An iframe needs a label that describes its purpose to screen reader users.
issueResolution:
Use the aria-label attribute to indicate the functionality of a given iframe like in the example below:

<iframe src="..." aria-label="YouTube tutorial video"></iframe>

name: Form Submissions Status
shortDescription: Submission statuses (success/failure) should be indicated to assistive technology
issueDescription: Screen reader users rely on status messages to automatically announce when a form is submitted. If status messages are not automatically announced, screen reader users will have to attempt to understand the status by browsing around picking clues.
issueResolution:
Include the role=alert attributes on the success/failure message of your forms.

Please note that the alert message should appear only once to announce the form status and not every field validation. Field validations should be handled separately.

<div role="alert">Thank you, we'll get back to you shortly.</div>

name: Enter Clickability
shortDescription: Interactive elements should be clickable using the Enter key
issueDescription: Only links with an href attribute, buttons, and a handful of other, less usable tags can be triggered using the Enter key by default. If you've used different elements and added JS click events to them, those elements are not operable using the keyboard.
issueResolution:
Add JavaScript to ensure that elements that are not clickable by default are clickable using the enter key. Alternatively, use native BUTTON and A HTML elements, which are keyboard clickable by default. Note that A tags (links) are only clickable if they include an HREF attribute.

If you choose to go the JavaScript route, you can copy and paste the below, which will add that functionality to your website. However, make sure to include your clickable selectors where the ".your-clickable-selectors" text appears. 

document.addEventListener('keydown', e => {
    if( e.which !== 13 || ['BUTTON', 'A'].includes(e.target.tagName) || ! e.target.closest('.your-clickable-selectors') ) return;
    e.target.click();
})

name: Button Roles
shortDescription: Buttons should be tagged for assistive technology
issueDescription: If interactive elements cannot be identified as buttons, screen reader users may not realize the element is actionable, which can stop them from submitting forms, opening dialogs, or performing other intended actions.
issueResolution:
Add role="button" to the custom navigation region, or use a HTML <button> element.

<button type="button">Button text</button>
<div role="button">Button text</div>
<span role="button">Button text</span>

name: New Window Links
shortDescription: Warning a user when a link triggers a new browser window is recommended
issueDescription: It's good practice to warn users about the expected behavior when activating a link triggers a new window.
issueResolution:
Add a visibly hidden text element that contains 'Opens new window'. Assign a unique id attribute to the element and add aria-describedby to the link, referencing the text element's id.

<!-- Visibly hidden text element with unique id -->
<span id="new-window-warning-1" class="sr-only">Opens new window</span>

<!-- Link with aria-describedby referencing the hidden text -->
<a href="https://example.com" target="_blank" aria-describedby="new-window-warning-1">
  Visit our website
</a>

name: Background Images
shortDescription: Non decorative Background images should be tagged and labeled
issueDescription: Background images should receive alternative text just like regular images do unless used as decorative elements and do not provide any information or additional context to the users.
issueResolution:
Use the screen-reader-only technique combined with the role="img" and aria-label attributes to indicate to screen readers that there's an image and the description for that image. Make sure to include the embedded text of the image alongside the objects that comprise it in the aria-label description.

Add role="img" to the first discernible sr-only element in the background image.

<div style="background-image: url(...)">
    <span class="sr-only" role="img" aria-label="Shop Tennis gear. Two people playing professional tennis in a stadium with spectators."></span>
</div>

name: Main Heading
shortDescription: Each page should have a main heading
issueDescription: There should be one h1 heading element that defines the subject of the main content on the page.
issueResolution:
Include single, descriptive, visible H1 (main header) on every page. Make sure that the header is placed where the content section of the page starts, and that it provides enough information to determine the page's topic.

<h1>I'm a main heading...</h1>

name: Active Tab
shortDescription: The active tab should be tagged as such for assistive technology
issueDescription: Screen readers require properly coded states for interactive elements. Tabs can have active and inactive states, and just like an active state usually is visually distinct, this should be indicated to screen reader users in the code.
issueResolution: Add the aria-selected=true to the active tab, alongside the role=tab to indicate that the element is indeed a tab. It's also essential to make sure to change the aria-selected=true to false when another tab becomes active (and that other tab should receive true).

name: Fake Hidden Content
shortDescription: Visibly hidden content should not be exposed to assistive technology
issueDescription: When elements are visually hidden but still exposed to assistive technology, screen reader users may encounter content that should not be available in the current interface. This can obscure the current state of the page and lead to confusion about what information or controls are available.
issueResolution:
Use aria-hidden="true" to remove elements from the accessibility tree when they should not be exposed to assistive technology.

<div aria-hidden="true">
  <p>This content is hidden from assistive technology</p>
</div>

Consider using CSS techniques, such as display:none or visibility:hidden when the content should be hidden from all users.

<!-- Using display: none -->
<div style="display: none;">
  <p>This content is hidden from all users</p>
</div>

<!-- Using visibility: hidden -->
<div style="visibility: hidden;">
  <p>This content is hidden from all users</p>
</div>

name: Broken Tabindex
shortDescription: The tabindex attribute should be assigned a valid value
issueDescription: Invalid tabindex values are ignored by browsers, while positive values override the natural focus order. Applying the tabindex attribute incorrectly can break the expected navigation flow for keyboard users.
issueResolution: If the element should be navigable, give it tabindex=0. If you've provided tabindex above 0 because you try to control focus order, then reorder elements in your HTML, but in any case, do not use tabindex above 0.

name: Incorrect Main Landmark
shortDescription: An element without main content is tagged as a main landmark
issueDescription: Incorrectly tagging the main landmark may cause screen reader users to misunderstand where the primary content begins or ends, leading to confusion and inefficient navigation.
issueResolution:
Reset the accessibility role of the inappropriate main area using the role=presentation attributes, or change the MAIN HTML tag to a DIV or a SECTION.

<main role="presentation"></main>

name: Broken Submenu Indication
shortDescription: ARIA relationship and state attributes should only be applied to elements with appropriate roles
issueDescription: Interactive elements that trigger additional content should only have relationship and state ARIA attributes, such as aria-expanded and aria-controls, if they have interactive roles, such as button, tab, combobox and in rarer cases, link.
issueResolution:
Make sure relationship and state ARIA attributes are only applied to elements with interactive roles, such as button, tab, and combobox. In rare cases, aria-expanded can be applied to link elements or elements with role="link", however this should only be done when the link both navigates and expands content.

<button aria-expanded="true" aria-haspopup="menu">Menu</button>
<a href="#" role="link" aria-expanded="true">Link that expands content</a>

name: Keyboard Navigation
shortDescription: Interactive elements should be keyboard navigable
issueDescription: Interactive elements should be keyboard navigable. If a custom interactive element is not keyboard navigable, keyboard users will not be able to interact with it.
issueResolution:
Add tabindex="0" to the custom interactive element.

<!-- Before: custom interactive element without tabindex -->
<div onclick="handleClick()">Click me</div>

<!-- After: custom interactive element with tabindex="0" -->
<div tabindex="0" onclick="handleClick()">Click me</div>

name: Letter Spacing
shortDescription: Letter spacing should scale to at least 0.12 times the font size without loss of content or functionality
issueDescription: When letter spacing is increased to 0.12 times the font size, text may be clipped, overlap, or overflow its container if styles like fixed widths, fixed heights, hidden overflow, or forced no-wrap prevent proper reflow.
issueResolution:
Do not use negative values in letter-spacing. Certain fonts look ok with up to -1px in letter spacing, but less than that is almost universally problematic.

<style>
body * {
    letter-spacing: 0;
}
</style>

name: Navigation Tagging
shortDescription: Navigation elements should be tagged as landmarks
issueDescription: Screen reader users have different controls to help them browse to specific elements on the page like regions and landmarks such as navigations. To ensure that screen readers can provide that functionality, navigation regions should be tagged accordingly.
issueResolution:
Add the role=navigation or code the navigation regions using the HTML NAV tag. Make sure to add an ARIA-LABEL to indicate the type of navigation. Is this the main navigation? Products navigation? Support navigation? No need to include the word "navigation" or "menu." Screen readers, by default, will announce that, like in the below example, which will be announced "Man's clothing navigation region".

<nav aria-label="Man's clothing">
    <ul>...</ul>
</nav>

name: Broken Nav Tagging
shortDescription: Avoid using role menu/menubar for navigation elements
issueDescription: Using role=menu and role=menubar for navigation elements is a bad practice, and screen reader users, especially JAWS users, find it difficult to operate. Those menu types are better used in desktop applications than web applications.
issueResolution:
Remove role="menu" or role="menubar" from the failing element.

<nav>
    <ul>
        <li><a href="#">Navigation Item</a></li>
    </ul>
</nav>

name: Popup Focus
shortDescription: Keyboard focus should move into and lock inside active dialogs
issueDescription: Dialogs that appear on pages without receiving keyboard focus immediately on interaction often leave users navigating content behind the dialog and make it difficult or impossible for keyboard and screen reader users to access the dialog itself.
issueResolution:
When a dialog opens, use JavaScript to place keyboard focus on the first interactive element within the dialog. If static content, such as lists, tables, or paragraphs, appears before any interactive elements and it needs to be perceived in order to easily understand the content, tabindex="-1" can be added to a static element at the start of the content to initially focus that element.

// Focus the first interactive element within the dialog
const dialog = document.querySelector('.dialog');
const firstInteractiveElement = dialog.querySelector('button, a, input, select, textarea, [tabindex]:not([tabindex="-1"])');
if (firstInteractiveElement) {
  firstInteractiveElement.focus();
}

// If static content needs to be focused first
const staticElement = dialog.querySelector('.dialog-content-start');
if (staticElement) {
  staticElement.setAttribute('tabindex', '-1');
  staticElement.focus();
}

name: Noninteractive Tabindex
shortDescription: Non-interactive elements should not be keyboard navigable
issueDescription: Allowing static content to receive keyboard focus creates unnecessary stops in the tab order, forcing users to tab through elements that provide no action and making keyboard navigation less intuitive.
issueResolution:
Remove the tabindex attribute from the static element.

<!-- Before: static element with tabindex -->
<div tabindex="0">Static content</div>

<!-- After: static element without tabindex -->
<div>Static content</div>

name: Column Table Headers
shortDescription: Table column headers should be tagged for assistive technology
issueDescription: If a column header is not marked up with the correct role or scope, screen reader users cannot determine which header applies to each cell.
issueResolution:
Use <th scope="col"> or assign role="columnheader" when building custom tables. Make sure each data cell is programmatically associated with the correct header so relationships are clear to assistive technology.

<table>
    <thead>
        <tr>
            <th scope="col">Name</th>
            <th scope="col">Age</th>
        </tr>
    </thead>
    <tbody>
        <tr>
            <td>John</td>
            <td>30</td>
        </tr>
    </tbody>
</table>

<!-- OR for custom tables -->
<div role="table">
    <div role="row">
        <div role="columnheader">Name</div>
        <div role="columnheader">Age</div>
    </div>
</div>

name: Main Landmark
shortDescription: Each web page that uses landmark regions should have a main landmark
issueDescription: A main landmark (e.g., <main>) lets screen reader users quickly skip past repeated elements and jump straight to the primary content, improving navigation and orientation.
issueResolution:
Where the main content on your page starts, give it role=main or engulf it with the MAIN HTML tag like in the example below:

<div role="main">
    <h1>Main page heading</h1>
</div>

name: Missing Nav Items
shortDescription: List items in a navigation region should not be interactive
issueDescription: Adding interactive behavior to <li> elements within a navigation list may prevent screen reader users from identifying the element as actionable, since <li> elements are announced as list items and expected to be static.
issueResolution:
Always include a link, button, or span/div tags as navigation items and avoid using direct text nodes even if functionality is provided using JS.

<nav>
    <ul>
        <li>Wrong: direct text node</li>
        <li><button>Correct: direct HTML element</button></li>
    </ul>
</nav>

name: Aria Label Misuse
shortDescription: aria-label should be used with compatible roles
issueDescription: Using aria-label on elements that do not support the attribute can lead to the label being ignored, leaving users without the intended information.
issueResolution:
Use a visually hidden element to provide the name or description instead of an aria-label.

<div>
    <span class="sr-only">Screen reader only content</span>
    .......
</div>

name: Skip Links
shortDescription: Skip links are the preferred technique for bypassing repeated content
issueDescription: Skip links let keyboard and screen reader users bypass repetitive navigation and jump directly to important sections such as main content, navigation, or footer. This improves efficiency, reduces keystrokes, and makes pages easier to use for those relying on assistive technology.
issueResolution:
Add skip links as the first focusable elements on the page, directing users to regions marked with unique ids and appropriate landmarks such as <main>, <nav>, or <footer>. Keep them visually hidden until focused so they don't clutter the layout, but ensure they remain accessible to screen readers by avoiding aria-hidden="true" or CSS display:none.

<style>
.skip-link {
    opacity: 0;
    position: absolute;
}

.skip-link:focus-visible {
    opacity: 1;
    position: static;
}
</style>

<body>
    <a href="#content" class="skip-link">Skip to content</a>
    <header></header>
    <nav></nav>
    <main id="content">
        <h1>Content</h1>
    </main>
    <footer></footer>
</body>

name: Article Setup
shortDescription: Only elements that function as articles should be tagged as article regions
issueDescription: Using an <article> tag on content that is not self-contained and that cannot stand on its own outside the context of the page, such as a blog post, news story, or forum entry, causes screen readers to announce misleading information about the purpose the content in relation to the main subject of the page.
issueResolution:
Assign role="presentation" to the failing element or use a different HTML tag that is more appropriate for the function of the element.

<article role="presentation"></article>

name: Custom Control Field
shortDescription: Custom checkbox and radio inputs should be made accessible
issueDescription: Screen readers have built-in mechanisms to handle checkboxes. By default, assistive technology does not support custom checkboxes, and using those may prevent screen reader users from interacting with the fields.
issueResolution:
If you are using standard LABEL and INPUT fields to design the custom checkbox using CSS, you need to ensure that the checkbox input is fully visible to assistive technology and the browser, but only visually hidden. To ensure that, you can hide it using opacity, width, height, and positioning, but never hide it using display=none or visibility=hidden.

<div>
    <label for="checkbox-input">Custom design</label>
    <input type="checkbox" id="checkbox-input" style="position: absolute; top: -100%, left: -100%, opacity: 0; width: 0, height: 0;">
</div>

Alternatively, if you are using a completely custom checkbox mechanism without a standard checkbox input, create a standard select field with all the options and make it available only for screen readers using the screen reader only technique. Then, hide the custom select box from screen readers using aria-hidden=true. Don't forget to add the same functionality to this hidden field as your custom one.

Using this method, screen readers will not "see" the custom field but will see the standard one and interact with it regularly.

<div class="checkbox" aria-hidden="true"></div>
<input type="checkbox" class="sr-only">

name: Misused Nav Tagging
shortDescription: An element without navigation links is tagged as a navigation landmark
issueDescription: Screen readers rely on accurate tagging and labeling to provide necessary context. If an element that does not contain navigation links is tagged as a navigation landmark, screen reader users may lose orientation and find the page's structure difficult to understand.
issueResolution: Add role="presentation" to the incorrect <nav> element or remove role="navigation" if a different element is used.

name: Broken Aria Reference
shortDescription: Aria describedby/labelledby must point to a valid, existing element ID
issueDescription: Screen readers rely on the HTML to provide explicit references between elements in order to parse the content and announce it to screen readers correctly. If the HTML includes broken ARIA references, screen reader users may not be able to browse properly.
issueResolution:
Make sure that aria-describedby and aria-labeledby attributes point to an existing, screen-reader-visible element on the screen with proper text content.

<button aria-describedby="button-description">Load more</button>
<span id="button-descriptionc">Additional gallery images will appear in a popup</span>

name: Load Autofocus
shortDescription: Avoid using autofocus
issueDescription: Make sure that no element has an autofocus attribute.
issueResolution: Remove the autofocus attribute from the element.

name: Table Layouts
shortDescription: Only elements that function as data tables should be tagged as table
issueDescription: When a layout table is marked up with HTML elements like <table> or <tr>, or assigned table ARIA roles, screen readers announce a data table structure with rows, columns, and headers, even though the table is only used for page layout.
issueResolution:
Avoid using table markup or roles for visual layout. Use CSS for page structure, and if a table must be used for layout, remove semantic roles by adding role="presentation" or role="none".

<!-- Use CSS for layout instead of tables -->
<div class="layout-container">
  <div class="column">Content</div>
  <div class="column">Content</div>
</div>

<!-- If table must be used for layout, remove semantic roles -->
<table role="presentation">
  <tr><td>Content</td><td>Content</td></tr>
</table>

<table role="none">
  <tr><td>Content</td><td>Content</td></tr>
</table>

name: Footer Landmark
shortDescription: Footer region should be correctly marked up
issueDescription: Ensure that the footer region is correctly marked up.
issueResolution:
Use the role=contentinfo alongside aria-label=footer attributes to indicate a footer contentinfo. Alternatively, you can code your footer using the FOOTER HTML tag which by default is treated as the contentinfo landmark by screen readers.

<div role="contentinfo" aria-label="footer"></div>
<footer></footer>

name: Breadcrumbs
shortDescription: Breadcrumbs navigation should be tagged properly
issueDescription: Breadcrumb navigation regions are essential for user orientation. If not appropriately tagged, screen reader users will not know that such an option exists on the page and will face more difficulties browsing around.
issueResolution:
Add a role=navigation or code the breadcrumbs using the HTML NAV tag. This will indicate to screen readers that it is a navigation region. Lastly, add an aria-label=Breadcrumbs attribute so screen readers can announce that to users.

<nav aria-label="Breadcrumbs"></nav>

name: Submenu Trigger Tagging
shortDescription: Menu trigger buttons/links should be tagged properly
issueDescription: Menu trigger buttons/links should have `aria-haspopup=true` or `aria-haspopup=menu` attribute
issueResolution:
Use the aria-haspopup attribute with value true or menu to indicate a menu trigger, and the aria-expanded=true to indicate expanded menus and aria-expanded=false to indicate collapsed menus. Make sure to switch between true and false dynamically as users interact, open and close menus.

Note: the aria-expanded attribute must be placed on the link or button menu items only. Otherwise, they won't work.

<button aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false">Menu</button>
<a href="#" aria-haspopup="menu" aria-expanded="false">Menu</a>

name: Noticeable Focus
shortDescription: Focused elements should not be obscured by a sticky header
issueDescription: All focusable elements must have a visible focus indicator when they receive keyboard focus.
issueResolution:
Add a CSS outline or other visual indicator to focusable elements to ensure the currently focused element can be visibly distinguished.

/* Using CSS outline */
*:focus-visible {
  outline: solid 2px #0066cc;
  outline-offset: 2px;
}

/* Using box-shadow as an alternative visual indicator */
*:focus-visible {
  box-shadow: 0 0 0 2px #0066cc;
}

/* Using border as a visual indicator */
*:focus-visible {
  border: 2px solid #0066cc;
}

name: Page Title
shortDescription: The HEAD element should include a descriptive page title
issueDescription: The document/page title is the first bit of context announced to screen reader users when a page loads. Without a properly descriptive document title, screen readers users won't know which page they've landed on.
issueResolution:
Include a descriptive title tag in the head portion of your HTML, on every page of your website.

<head>
<title>I'm the page title</title>
...
</head>

name: Headless Tables
shortDescription: Tables should include table header tags
issueDescription: Screen readers can't match columns and cells without properly coded table header tags (TH). Without table headers, screen readers won't announce the table's content properly to users, leaving them unable to consume information.
issueResolution:
Add a THEAD element to indicate a table heading section, and include TH elements for every column, describing the purpose of that table column. 

<thead>
    <tr>
        <th>Header1</th>
        <th>Header2</th>
        <th>Header3</th>
    </tr>
<thead>

name: Empty Links
shortDescription: Empty links should indicate their location or excluded from assistive technology
issueDescription: Screen reader users need to figure out a link's destination based on the text or a coded label. This is because they interact with one element at a time and don't see visual cues that provide more context.
issueResolution:
Use an aria-label or the screen-reader-only text technique to provide links with extra context regarding  their destination and functionality like in the example below:

<a href="...."><span class="sr-only">Blog article: 10 different ways to...</span></a>
<a href="...." aria-label="Blog article: 10 different ways to..."></a>

name: Color Contrast
shortDescription: The color contrast ratio between text and its background should provide a readable experience
issueDescription: The color contrast between the foreground and the background elements needs to meet a ratio of at least 4.5:1 for standard text. For large text above 18pt (24px) font size, a lower ratio of 3:1 can be met, but it is recommended to remain with 4:5:1 in any case. A background element that is not directly in the hierarchy of the text element that has the correct contrast, may cause what appears to be a false positive. According to WCAG, this is incorrect, and not a false positive because people using assistive technologies may change the font and background colors to improve readability, which isn't possible if the background is not part of the text element's hierarchy.
issueResolution:
Work with the website's designers to choose colors that properly meet the minimum contrast ratio requirements. To check color contrast with different potential colors, use Webaim's contrast checker: https://webaim.org/resources/contrastchecker

If using floating backgrounds, ensure they are part of the hierarchy of the text element to allow users with assistive technologies to adjust colors for better readability.

name: Sale Prices
shortDescription: Original and discounted prices should be indicated to assistive technology
issueDescription: Discounted prices often appear next to the original and distinguished with visual cues like strikethroughs or color changes. Both prices must also be conveyed by screen readers in a way that enables users to differentiate between the values, ensuring they can understand when a discount is applied.
issueResolution:
Add visually hidden text that explicitly identifies each value as the original price or the discounted price.

<div>$100 <span class="sr-only">Original price</span></div>
<div>$75 <span class="sr-only">Discounted price</span></div>

name: Field Required
shortDescription: Mandatory form fields should indicate that they are required
issueDescription: If a field is marked as required only through visual cues, but lacks the required attribute or aria-required="true", screen readers will not announce it as mandatory. As a result, users may experience unnecessary delays or confusion when trying to submit the form.
issueResolution:
Add the aria-required=true attribute to indicate to screen readers that a field is required and the form won't submit without it.

<input aria-required="true">

name: Submenu State
shortDescription: Triggers that expand additional content should expose their state to assistive technology
issueDescription: When components such as accordions or navigation menus do not expose their state, screen reader users may not realize that additional content can be revealed or know whether it is currently visible.
issueResolution:
When a button is a menu trigger, you should connect it to the menu it toggles using the aria-controls attribute on the button, where the value is the id of the menu. Use the aria-expanded attribute to indicate whether the menu controlled by a menu-trigger button is expanded or collapsed (if it is visible or not). Set the value dynamically to true when the menu is visible and false when it is not.

Note: the aria-expanded attribute must be placed on the link or button menu items only. Otherwise, they won't work.

<button aria-controls="menu1" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true">Menu</button>
<div id="menu1">...</div>

name: Title Misuse
shortDescription: The title attribute should not be the only method used to provide information
issueDescription: The title attribute is announced inconsistently across screen readers and browsers, making it unreliable for labeling interactive controls. Because many users may never hear the content, reliance on the attribute risks loss of information. Instead, it should be used to provide extra help text in addition to a valid label.
issueResolution:
Make sure that the title attribute is not the only means of providing a label by assigning an aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute to the interactive control.

<button title="Submit form" aria-label="Submit form">Submit</button>
<input type="text" title="Enter your name" aria-label="Enter your name">
<div title="Navigation menu" aria-labelledby="nav-label">
  <span id="nav-label">Navigation menu</span>
</div>

name: Live Carousels
shortDescription: Carousels should not be tagged as live regions
issueDescription: When carousels are tagged as live regions, screen readers will interrupt reading and announce every slide change, even when the user isn't interacting with the carousel or is in another section entirely.
issueResolution: Remove the aria-live=true attribute from the carousel itself and all of its slides.

name: Broken Nav Items
shortDescription: Avoid using role="menuitem" for web navigation links
issueDescription: In most cases, using ARIA menu roles within a web page can negatively impact screen reader users, especially those using JAWS. role="menuitem" should be used for menu items in menu types that function like those found in desktop applications.
issueResolution:
Use standard lists with links and buttons (or custom buttons with role="button") and remove role="menuitem".

<!-- Before: using role="menuitem" -->
<ul role="menu">
  <li role="menuitem">Home</li>
  <li role="menuitem">About</li>
</ul>

<!-- After: standard list with links -->
<ul>
  <li><a href="/home">Home</a></li>
  <li><a href="/about">About</a></li>
</ul>

<!-- After: standard list with buttons -->
<ul>
  <li><button>Action 1</button></li>
  <li><button>Action 2</button></li>
</ul>

<!-- After: standard list with custom buttons (role="button") -->
<ul>
  <li><span role="button" tabindex="0">Custom Button</span></li>
</ul>

name: Carousel Labeling
shortDescription: Carousels should be tagged and labeled properly
issueDescription: Unlabeled carousel areas are difficult for screen reader users because content gets hidden and shown unexpectedly. This can cause screen readers to read, stop, and start to read again something else entirely. If tagged properly, this behavior is expected.
issueResolution:
Use the ARIA landmark technique to tag the carousel as a region, alongside an "aria-label" that equals "carousel". Using both of these attributes, assistive technology users will understand that this is a carousel region. This will also help users identify that buttons and controls within the region (like next, previous, or pause) are associated with controlling the carousel functionality.

You can also include extra content for the carousel in the aria-label attribute as seen in the example below: 

<div class="carousel" role="region" aria-label="Featured Products Carousel"></div>

name: Carousel Pagination
shortDescription: Carousel pagination buttons should be tagged and labled for assistive technology
issueDescription: Carousel pagination buttons, which are usually tiny dots indicating a slide option, are often used for operating carousels. However, if those aren't tagged and coded correctly for screen-readers, blind users won't be able to operate the carousel.
issueResolution:
For pagination buttons to be accessible, they should either be built as native buttons or use the role=button attribute. They should also include a screen-reader-only text or an "aria-label" to indicate the slide number they activate.

<button type="button" aria-label="Carousel slide 1/2/3"></button>
<button type="button"><span class="sr-only">Carousel slide 1/2/3</span></button>

name: Viewport Scalability
shortDescription: Meta viewport tag should alow user scaling of at least 200%
issueDescription: The page needs to enable pinch-zoom and software Zoom for assistive technology - at least 200% the basic size without breaking the layout or clipping the content.
issueResolution:
The meta viewport enables the Zoom behavior by default if we provide correct values. Make sure the user-scalable portion of the attribute is set to yes, and that the maximum-scale portion is at least 2 (200%). Ideally, set it to 5.

<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, user-scalable=yes, initial-scale=1.0, maximum-scale=5.0, minimum-scale=1.0">

name: Captcha
shortDescription: CAPTCHA used in authentication should not involve cognitive function tests
issueDescription: With the exception of challenges that require recognition of  objects that are generally familiar to users, CAPTCHA used during authentication should not require users to perform cognitive function tests, such as recalling site-specific passwords or solving a puzzle.
issueResolution: Replace all non-standard Captcha fields with Google Recaptcha (or other Accessible Provider) which is fully accessible for screen readers and assistive technology by default. Learn more about Google Recaptcha here: https://www.google.com/recaptcha/about/

name: Broken Aria Labels
shortDescription: Aria labels should not override or replace visible text
issueDescription: Aria labels should describe elements that don't have proper text, like icons and field labels. It should not be used to override element texts. Screen reader users need to receive the exact text as visually on the screen, with more context if it is ambiguous. An exception applies to landmarks such as nav or other landmarks: here, ARIA labels can provide additional context or clarification.
issueResolution:
Remove the aria-label. If you need to add context for screen reader users only because of the ambiguity of the text, use the screen-reader-only technique.

<span class="sr-only">Additional context</span>

name: Carousel Pausing
shortDescription: Carousel should include a pause button
issueDescription: Carousels without a properly labeled button to allow users to pause may cause interference with assistive technology and loss of orientation for keyboard navigation users.
issueResolution:
Include a keyboard-navigable, labeled button that enables users to pause the carousel. If you do not want the button to be visible but only available for screen readers and keyboard users, you can hide it using the CSS opacity attribute (set to 0), and on focus, set the opacity to 1 to make it visible.

<button type="button" class="pause-button">Pause</button>
<style>
.pause-button {
    opacity: 0;
}

.pause-button:focus-visible {
    opacity: 1;
}
</style>

name: Tabs Tagging
shortDescription: Tabs should be tagged properly for assistive technology
issueDescription: Tabs are a very popular way to provide information on demand. However, If tabs aren't adequately tagged and labeled, screen reader users will most likely miss the entire content hidden within the inactive tabs, never knowing additional information exists.
issueResolution: Add role=tab to the buttons which trigger the tab functionality.

name: Tab Panel Tagging
shortDescription: Tab panels should be tagged for assistive technology
issueDescription: Tagging the tab triggers is essential but isn't enough. The tag panels should also be tagged appropriately to provide context. Otherwise, screen reader users won't know if the content being read is part of the tab functionality or just random text on the page.
issueResolution: Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry. Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s.

name: Custom Select Field
shortDescription: Custom select fields should be made accessible
issueDescription: Screen readers have built-in mechanisms to handle select fields. By default, assistive technology does not support custom select fields, and using those may prevent screen reader users from interacting with the fields.
issueResolution:
Create a standard select field with all the options and make it available only for screen readers using the screen reader only technique. Then, hide the custom select box from screen readers using aria-hidden=true. Don't forget to add the same functionality to this hidden field as your custom one.

 Using this method, screen readers will not "see" the custom field but will see the standard one and interact with it regularly.

<div class="custom-select" aria-hidden="true">
    <ul>
        <li>Option 1</li>
        <li>Option 2</li>
        <li>Option 3</li>
    </ul>
</div>
<select class="sr-only">
    <option>Option 1</option>
    <option>Option 2</option>
    <option>Option 3</option>
</select>

name: Submenu Operability
shortDescription: Sub-menu should open and close using the Enter key
issueDescription: Clicking Enter when a menu item with a sub-menu is focused should open the sub-menu. A second click should close it. If sub-menus are not operable using the keyboard, screen reader and keyboard users may miss a significant part of the website.
issueResolution: Enable opening and closing sub-menus using the Enter key. If the menu item is a link, disable the link's behavior. Otherwise, rather than opening the menu, users will be redirected). However, make sure there's a link within the sub-menu that will take users to the designated menu item link that has been disabled. This menu item can be a screen-reader-only link.

name: Marquee
shortDescription: <marquee> elements are deprecated
issueDescription: <marquee> elements are obsolete and should not be used. They are not part of any HTML or WAI-ARIA specification. They are not responsive or supported by any browsers.
issueResolution: Remove the marquee element and use a different method of animating text like carousels or CSS transitions and animations.

name: Keyboard Hoverables
shortDescription: Mouse hoverables should receive keyboard focus no function the same as with the mouse
issueDescription: Elements that appear or change behavior on mouse hover should also appear on keyboard focus and provide the same functionality. Otherwise, keyboard users will not be able to interact with those elements.
issueResolution:
As a general rule of thumb, it is best practice to avoid providing functionality only on mouse hover. The biggest reason for that is touch screens like mobile devices and tablets (and many laptops). Touch input does not include a hover functionality because the interaction isn't with a mouse. This is also true for accessibility - keyboards and assistive technology do not have a "hover" functionality.

If you still wish to include hover functionality, in order to make it accessible, you'll need to use JavaScript rather than CSS to make it work. Using JavaScript, add a focusing event to the hoverable element to catch when it is being focused using the keyboard (don't forget to give it tabindex=0). Then, add a class, and make the hover CSS apply to that class as well. Lastly, add a focusout event to remove the class when the element is no longer focused.

You can copy and paste the below JavaScript code, but make sure to include your actual selectors instead of the ".your-hoverable-selector" and ".your-hoverable-class" texts.

document.addEventListener('focusin', e => {
   if( e.target.closest('.your-hoverable-selector') ) e.target.classList.add('.your-hoverable-class'); 
});

document.addEventListener('focusout', e => {
   if( ! e.target.matches('.your-hoverable-selector') ||  ) e.target.parentElement.closest('.your-hoverable-selector') ) return;
   e.target.classList.remove('.your-hoverable-class');
});

name: Carousel Arrows
shortDescription: Carousel navigation arrows should be labled for assistive technology
issueDescription: Carousel arrow buttons (next/previous slides) are essential for operating carousels. By design, carousels are difficult for assistive technology to handle. If the navigation arrows aren't accessible, carousels may be impossible for blind users to operate.
issueResolution:
Build the arrow buttons using a button tag. Alternatively, use the ARIA-role (role=button) attribute to mark those as buttons for assistive technology. Additionally, include an aria-label or a screen-reader-only text describing the functionality of the button.

<button type="button" aria-label="Next/Previous">... YOUR ARROW ICON</button>
<button type="button"><span class="sr-only">Next/Previous</span>... YOUR ARROW ICON</button>

name: Alt Text
shortDescription: Functional images should have a text alternative
issueDescription: Images require a text alternative when the image conveys meaningful content or serves a functional purpose. If the image is decorative, it must be hidden from assistive technology.
issueResolution:
If the image is meaningful, assign a text alternative with a description of the image content using the alt attribute for image elements, or aria-label for elements with role="img". If the image is decorative, provide an empty alt attribute for image elements, or role="presentation" for elements with role="img".

<!-- Meaningful image with alt attribute -->
<img src="product.jpg" alt="Red leather handbag with gold hardware">

<!-- Meaningful element with role="img" using aria-label -->
<div role="img" aria-label="Company logo featuring a mountain silhouette">
  <svg>...</svg>
</div>

<!-- Decorative image with empty alt attribute -->
<img src="decorative-border.png" alt="">

<!-- Decorative element with role="img" using role="presentation" -->
<div role="presentation">
  <svg>...</svg>
</div>

name: Row Table Headers
shortDescription: Table row headers should be tagged for assistive technology
issueDescription: If a table row header is not marked up with the correct role or scope, screen reader users cannot determine which header applies to each cell.
issueResolution:
Use <th scope="row"> or assign role="rowheader" when building custom tables. Make sure each data cell is programmatically associated with the correct header so relationships are clear to assistive technology.

<table>
    <tr>
        <th scope="row">Row header</th>
        <td>Cell</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
        <td role="rowheader">Row header</td>
        <td>Cell</td>
    </tr>
</table>

name: Popup Tagging
shortDescription: Modal dialogs should be tagged for assistive technology
issueDescription: Content behind active modal dialogs should not be navigable, otherwise screen reader users may still encounter hidden or unrelated content, disrupting the intended workflow and making it harder to focus on the dialogs purpose.
issueResolution:
Add aria-modal="true" alongside role="dialog" to indicate to screen readers that the dialog is modal and that content outside of it should be treated as inactive. Screen readers will recognize this and adjust their behavior to keep the user's focus inside the dialog, providing a clearer and more predictable experience.

<div role="dialog" aria-modal="true">...</div>

<dialog aria-modal="true">...</dialog>

name: Search Form Tagging
shortDescription: A search form should be tagged as a search landmark
issueDescription: Screen reader users rely on landmarks to quickly access important regions of a page. Defining a form as a search landmark ensures that users can quickly recognize and navigate to the search form.
issueResolution:
Enclose the search form in a <search> element or assign role="search" to the <form> element.

<search>
    <form>
        <input type="search" />
    </form>
</search>

<form role="search">
    <input type="search" />
</form>

name: Role Applications
shortDescription: Avoid using role="application"
issueDescription: Using role="application" is generally discouraged because it disables standard screen reader modes and forces users into an application mode. This removes familiar navigation shortcuts, such as heading or landmark navigation, and requires them to interact in ways they may not expect.
issueResolution:
Remove role="application" from the failing element.

<!-- Before -->
<div role="application">Content</div>

<!-- After -->
<div>Content</div>

name: Fake Hidden Interactive
shortDescription: Visually hidden elements should not receive keyboard focus
issueDescription: Hiding elements on screen using any other method than display=none or visibility=hidden keeps them keyboard-navigable. Therefore when users navigate, they'll focus on those elements but won't see anything focused on-page and lose orientation.
issueResolution:
If you are hiding elements using opacity, size, positioning, or any other CSS method other than display=none or visibility=hidden, add all interactive elements inside this "hidden" element tabindex=-1. This includes links, buttons, and form fields.

When this "hidden" element becomes visible on screen, remove the tabindex=-1 for any native links, buttons, and form fields in it (those elements are keyboard navigable by default), and add tabindex=0 to interactive elements that aren't coded as links or buttons link SPAN, DIV, I and other interactive elements bound by JS.

<a href="..." tabindex="-1">This link will not be keyboard navigable</a>

name: Ambiguous Links
shortDescription: Ambiguous links should have additional descriptions for screen readers.
issueDescription: Ambiguous links like "Learn More", "Shop Now" and "Start Here" are often used as a call to action. However, screen-reader users, while using link navigation, do not interact with content above or below the link and therefore don't have the same context as to what they will learn more about.
issueResolution:
Add a screen-reader only text which gives additional context to the destination of the link such as the example below:

<a href="...">Shop Now <span class="sr-only">New summer collection</span></a>

name: Decorative Content
shortDescription: Meaningful icons should have a label, while decorative icons should be hidden
issueDescription: Smaller graphics used as decorative or complementary elements, such as icons, and that do not provide additional information will often add unnecessary clutter to a screen reader user's browsing experience.
issueResolution:
If the image is meaningful, assign a text alternative with a description of the image content using the alt attribute for image elements, or aria-label for elements with role="img". If the image is decorative, provide an empty alt attribute for image elements, or role="presentation" for elements with role="img".

<!-- Meaningful image -->
<img src="icon.png" alt="Search">
<svg role="img" aria-label="Search"></svg>

<!-- Decorative image -->
<img src="decoration.png" alt="">
<svg role="presentation"></svg>

name: Figure Setup
shortDescription: Figure elements should receive text description or lose figure role
issueDescription: Figure elements are often incorrectly used to display images on the screen. Incorrectly using the figure tag, without providing a proper figcaption, adds unnecessary clutter to the screen reader user's experience.
issueResolution:
Standard images should be coded regularly without having a figure parent element. The figure tag should only be used for images you wish to provide additional visual descriptions for, like the date and time a photo was taken or other metadata.

To make a figure tag non-cluttering for screen-readers, add the role=presentation attribute to replace it with another element like DIV. Alternatively, if you did intend to use the figure tag, make sure to add a figcaption tag with the additional metadata.

<figure role="presentation"><img src="..." alt="Image alt"></figure>
<figure><img src="..." alt="Image alt"><figcaption>January 2020, 10 AM, Milano Italy.</figcaption></figure>

name: Field Label
shortDescription: Form fields must include a descriptive label
issueDescription: Screen readers rely on properly coded, associated labels to identify a field's purpose and read it to the user. Without properly coding the connection between the label and the input, blind users won't be able to interact with the form.
issueResolution:
Provide a LABEL tag and associate it to the field using the for and the id attributes like in the example below. Alternatively, you can put an aria-label attribute directly on the field without including an associated label tag.

<div>
    <label for="field-id">Field label</label>
    <input id="field-id">
</div>
--------- OR ---------
<input aria-label="Field label">

name: Field Validations
shortDescription: Fields must indicate validation errors to assistive technology
issueDescription: Screen reader users rely on properly coded field validation status and associated validation messages. Otherwise, users would have to browse around and try to pick up clues on the page as to why their submission attempt did not work.
issueResolution:
Include the aria-invalid=true attribute when the field validation shows on the page. Screen readers will pick that up and inform the user that this field is invalid. Make sure to change the aria-invalid to false when the field value does become valid.

To associate validation messages with fields, use the aria-describedby attribute and give it the field's ID for which it provides a validation message. Alternatively, put the validation message inside the associated field LABEL, causing screen readers to announce it on interaction.

<input aria-labeledby="phone-validation" aria-label="Phone number">
<span id="phone-validation">Please enter exactly 10 digits</span>

name: Field Validation Focus
shortDescription: Keyboard focus should move into the invalid field on submission
issueDescription: When field validations appear, if the keyboard focus doesn't automatically land on an incorrect field, it is often difficult for screen reader and keyboard users to identify and navigate to the error message and start fixing the form from there.
issueResolution:
Automatically move the keyboard focus into the first errored field on unsuccessful form submission.

document.querySelector('#field-id').focus()

name: Submenu Tagging
shortDescription: Tagging submenus is recommended
issueDescription: Complex menu structures often contain multiple groups of links that can feel like undifferentiated page content to screen reader users. Assigning role="region" with a label makes each submenu a distinct, named section, clarifying its relationship to the trigger and improving orientation.
issueResolution:
Assign role="region" to each menu panel so screen reader users can distinguish submenus from surrounding page content. Adding a label (e.g., with aria-labelledby) helps users quickly identify each panel within a complex menu structure.

<nav>
    <ul>
        <li>
            <a href="...">Menu item</a>
            <div class="sub-menu" role="region" aria-labelledby="submenu-label">
                <span id="submenu-label" class="sr-only">Submenu</span>
                ...
            </div>
        </li>
    </ul>
</nav>

name: Nested Navigation
shortDescription: Avoid using nested navigation structure
issueDescription: Complex navigation components can be difficult for screen readers to handle. This is especially true if submenus or other complex structures exist. Nesting navigation regions makes it harder for screen reader users to understand a page's structure and disrupts orientation.
issueResolution:
If the failing element is a custom navigation region, remove role="navigation". If the failing element is coded using a HTML <nav> tag, apply role="presentation" or a role that is suitable for the function of the element.

<!-- Custom navigation region: remove role="navigation" -->
<div role="navigation">
  <ul>
    <li><a href="#">Home</a></li>
  </ul>
  <div role="navigation"><!-- Remove role="navigation" from this nested element -->
    <ul>
      <li><a href="#">Submenu item</a></li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</div>

<!-- HTML <nav> tag: apply role="presentation" -->
<nav>
  <ul>
    <li><a href="#">Menu item</a></li>
    <nav role="presentation">
      <ul>
        <li><a href="#">Submenu item</a></li>
      </ul>
    </nav>
  </ul>
</nav>

name: Broken List
shortDescription: List items should not exist outside of a list element
issueDescription: When list items are not contained in a list element, screen readers will not announce them as list items, preventing users from understanding the content as part of a structured list.
issueResolution:
Enclose the list items in an <ol>, <ul>, or an element with role="list".

<!-- Before: list items without a parent list -->
<li>Item 1</li>
<li>Item 2</li>
<li>Item 3</li>

<!-- After: using <ul> -->
<ul>
  <li>Item 1</li>
  <li>Item 2</li>
  <li>Item 3</li>
</ul>

<!-- After: using <ol> -->
<ol>
  <li>Item 1</li>
  <li>Item 2</li>
  <li>Item 3</li>
</ol>

<!-- After: using role="list" -->
<div role="list">
  <div role="listitem">Item 1</div>
  <div role="listitem">Item 2</div>
  <div role="listitem">Item 3</div>
</div>

name: Language Report
shortDescription: The HTML element should include a proper "lang" attribute
issueDescription: For screen readers to know which language to announce the content to the users, they need to receive information about the dominant language of the page from the HTML tag of the document.
issueResolution:
Include a lang attribute with the language code of the dominant language of the page, directly on the HTML tag. You can use only the two first characters of the language code, for example, use en rather than en-us or en-gb.

<html lang="en/es/fr/de/ru...">

name: Long Headings
shortDescription: Heading should be concise
issueDescription: The main heading of the document should be concise and descriptive. It should not be too lengthy (less than 160 chars).
issueResolution:
To reset the heading role of an element you can either add the role=presentation attribute, or completely change the HTML tag from a heading tag to a SPAN, DIV, or a P (paragraph) tag.

<h3 role="presentation"></h3>

name: Multiple Main Headings
shortDescription: A page should not have more than one main heading
issueDescription: Each web page should have only one h1 element so that screen reader users can identify the main topic or purpose of the page. Multiple h1s can confuse users by suggesting there are multiple primary topics, disrupting navigation by headings and making it harder to understand the overall page structure.
issueResolution:
Make sure that each web page has exactly one h1 element so that screen reader users can identify the main subject of the page.

<!-- Correct: One h1 element per page -->
<h1>Main Page Title</h1>
<h2>Section Heading</h2>
<p>Content here...</p>
<h2>Another Section</h2>
<p>More content...</p>

<!-- Incorrect: Multiple h1 elements -->
<h1>First Main Heading</h1>
<h1>Second Main Heading</h1> <!-- Change this to h2 or another heading level -->

name: Missing Form Button
shortDescription: Form submission controls should have type="submit"
issueDescription: Adding type="submit" to a control that submits a form ensures that screen readers users expect a change of context when they activate the control.
issueResolution:
Include a submit button in your form. If the form doesn't technically require a visible submit button, including one just for screen readers using the screen-reader-only technique. This will provide the necessary clarity for screen reader users.

<button type="submit" class="sr-only">Submit</button>

name: Scroll Focus
shortDescription: Move focus to relevant element when a click has scroled the page
issueDescription: If the page scrolls to a different location after an element is clicked, the keyboard focus should move with the scroll. Otherwise, the next Tab key hit (attempt to navigate with the keyboard) will take the user back to the location before the scroll.
issueResolution:
When users click elements that scroll the page (like scroll to top/scroll to bottom), use JavaScript like the example below to focus the element or area they scroll to. If the element to focus isn't focusable by default (like links and buttons), giving it tabindex=-1 will make it keyboard focusable but exclude it from tab navigation.

Note: the preventScroll argument in the object passed to the scroll function tells the browser not to re-scroll the page.

document.querySelector('.element-to-focus').focus({preventScroll: true})

name: Inline Popup Focus
shortDescription: Move focus into revealed element after trigger
issueDescription: If an element because visible after clicking on another element, keyboard focus should move into that newly visible element. Otherwise, screen reader users will not know something has changed on the page.

name: SVG Content
shortDescription: SVG discernible
issueDescription: All SVGs that are not used in the context of button icons must have discernible text.
issueResolution:
Add a text alternative to the SVG.

<svg aria-label="Descriptive text for the SVG">
  <rect width="50" height="50" style="fill:rgb(0,0,255);" />
</svg>

<svg aria-labelledby="svg-label">
  <rect width="50" height="50" style="fill:rgb(0,0,255);" />
</svg>
<span id="svg-label">Descriptive text for the SVG</span>

<svg>
  <title>Descriptive text for the SVG</title>
  <rect width="50" height="50" style="fill:rgb(0,0,255);" />
</svg>

name: Hidden Visible Content
shortDescription: Visible content should not be hidden from assistive technology
issueDescription: If content remains visible on the screen but assigned aria-hidden="true", it will be excluded from the accessibility tree. As a result, screen reader users will not have access to the same information as sighted users.
issueResolution:
For visible content, ensure that it is not marked with aria-hidden="true" or presented in such a way that screen readers and other assistive technologies cannot perceive it. Instead, use appropriate semantic HTML elements and ARIA roles to describe the content and its purpose. Here is an example of visible content that should be accessible to assistive technologies: 

<!-- Incorrect: Content is visible but hidden from assistive technology -->
<div aria-hidden="true">Important content here</div>

<!-- Correct: Content is visible and accessible to assistive technology -->
<div>Important content here</div>

name: Multiple Main Landmarks
shortDescription: Each page should include at most one main landmark
issueDescription: A page typically presents one central subject, so a single main landmark establishes the boundaries of the primary content for screen reader users. Multiple main landmarks create uncertainty about the scope, leading to confusion and difficulty navigating the page.
issueResolution:
Keep only the true primary area as <main> or role="main", and change others to suitable elementssuch as <section>, <nav>, or a neutral <div>. In modular or single-page apps, only the active view should expose a main landmark; remove the role or unmount inactive modules, or hide them with hidden or display:none.

<!-- Keep only one main landmark -->
<main>
  <h1>Primary Content</h1>
  <p>Main page content here...</p>
</main>

<!-- Change other main elements to suitable alternatives -->
<section>
  <h2>Secondary Content</h2>
  <p>Additional content...</p>
</section>

<!-- For modular/single-page apps: hide inactive modules -->
<main>Active View Content</main>
<main hidden>Inactive View Content</main>

<!-- Or use CSS to hide -->
<main style="display: none;">Inactive View Content</main>
